title: 113_hr2652
content: The "Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2013" is also known as the Safe Harbor for Depository Institutions. A Federal banking regulator is prohibited from terminating deposit insurance or discouraging financial services to marijuana-related legitimate businesses. They cannot recommend against offering financial services to individuals involved in marijuana manufacturing. The Federal banking regulator cannot take action against deposit insurance or financial services for marijuana-related legitimate businesses or individuals involved in marijuana manufacturing. PROTECTIONS UNDER FEDERAL LAW. Depository institutions providing financial services to marijuana-related businesses and their employees are immune from federal prosecution or investigation. They cannot be held liable under federal criminal law for offering these services or reinvesting income from them. Additionally, institutions with a legal interest in collateral for loans to marijuana businesses are protected from criminal, civil, or forfeiture actions. Depository institutions with a legal interest in collateral for loans to marijuana businesses are protected from criminal, civil, or forfeiture actions. SEC. 4. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not mandate depository institutions to offer financial services to marijuana-related legitimate businesses. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM FILING SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY REPORTS. SEC. 5 amends Section 5318(g) of title 31, exempting marijuana-related legitimate businesses from filing suspicious activity reports. The Secretary will not require depository institutions to report such transactions solely based on involvement with these businesses. Definitions are provided in the Marijuana Businesses Access to Banking Act of 2013. In this Act, "depository institution" refers to a bank, credit union, or similar financial institution. "Federal banking regulator" includes various government agencies overseeing banking activities. The curr_chunk defines terms related to banking, financial services, manufacturers, and marijuana-related legitimate businesses. The curr_chunk defines terms related to marijuana and marijuana products, including producers and states. The term "State" in the context refers to each of the several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and any territory or possession of the United States.
